div.head: 6.1.1883 Samstag
div.p:
Drove to the rue de Rivoli where we arrived at 9. Papa and I stopped downstairs in the arcades where we bought sundry photographies of Gambetta. It was really amazing to see where the crowd had got to. One man had got on to one of the flower pots which form part of the railings of the Tuileries. How he got up is a mystery. But how he got down is not as he did that pretty precipitately owing to being nearly suffocated by the smoke of a chimney which opened just under him. At about a quarter to ten we went up to Misses Keogh’s, and at the same time some „cantonniers“ began pelting the people with sand, by way of clearing the road. And they really did hit some people on the head with it. At about 10.30 the Garde de Paris turned the corner of the Rue de Rivoli, followed by some policemen to clear the way, a by no means easy operation. Then followed the deputations of Alsace-Lorraine with some very fine flowers, after them came some pompes funèbres à cheval, then three carriages each drawn by four horses covered with flowers. On each side of these carriages walked sixteen men, in black knee breeches and with a silver chain around their necks, two and two each pair carrying two huge wreathes on sticks; and behind came a single man carrying an enormous wreath too. After this came some soldiers, and then the hearse. The hearse was made of a low kind of truck with enormous silver wheels. On this truck stood the lower part of the catafalque of the rue de Bourbon without the columns and dais; at each corner of the catafalque were antique incense burners covered over with crape. On the catafalque stood the coffin in a tricolore flag, with an enormous piece of velvet, half covering it and falling down nearly to the ground at the back of it. Then came some more Alsace Lorraine people, and a lot of freemaçons; there was also a deputation from Martinique with about twenty niggers, and a deputation from Algeria with some splendid flowers. At the sight of anything prettier than the rest the people cried "bis, bis". Among other things a large triangle of violets was conspicuous as well as a flag bearing an English inscription, something about french brethren, and liberty, equality fraternity. The flowers were magnificent. After all these deputations, among almost every one of which were women and among some like the freemasons children, came the garrison of Paris and Versailles which closed the procession. In the afternoon I drove to the Palais Bourbon to see the decorations. A large piece of crape, 150 meters long they say, was draped across the whole front and the background was formed by black woollen stuff draped on the wall behind the columns, decorated with flags and palms. Between the columns stood large silver candlesticks and the whole staircase was covered with wreathes and flowers. The statue of Strasburg
Pradier was draped in black but not the lanterns. The steps were covered with wreathes. Played with Gee the rest of the afternoon, and went away tonight.
